ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the biochemical and biophysical processes and mechanisms underlying cancer development and progression. I learned about the ways in which MatLab can be used to model tumorigenesis, as well as how to more effectively read, understand, and present primary literature papers.
understanding the field of cellular biophysics and its application to the immune system. current investigations and research areas regarding cancer.

Analyzing the various aspects of cancer from a biophysical/mechanical perspective; aspects of the tumor microenvironment and the interactions of cells with ECM. How to computationally model and simulate cell migration, viscoelastic ECM networks, and catch/slip bonds.
We learned about a broad array of techniques to investigate cancer. I also practiced my presenting skills during the student lead classes, as well as doing literature reviews.
Literature search and review. Quantitative analysis
Research and techniques in the study of cancer cell-related phenomena.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I appreciated the journal club-based format of the class. It was also nice that the class was so small, as it created a really friendly environment. I also felt like there were an adequate number of problem sets and assignments throughout the semester, though I would have much preferred only a final paper/project, and not a final exam as well. 
Weaknesses: The constant format of 60 minutes of presenting a paper followed by 50 minutes of Professor Mak lecturing got a little repetitive at times and made the class difficult to sit through for 110 minutes. Maybe a five minute break between the paper presentation and Professor Mak's presentation would be helpful? Problem set grades were also released very slowly and made it difficult to know how we were doing throughout the semester.
i liked the weekly assignments and readings - there was a good mix of topics

Strengths: Amazing course material and Dr. Mak is a fantastic professor who is supportive of students. The presentation format allowed everyone to dive deeply into the papers they chose.
Weaknesses: The reading responses were not always the best way to assess learning. Some other way to test our knowledge of the papers would have been good.

The course is an interesting set up, I enjoyed how the students would lead lectures and then the professor would follow up after.  The matlab was interesting and fairly easy to use. It could be improved with a bit more continuity between weeks, but overall good course.
The class is oriented around student driven discovery and reading, which encourage the study of subjects based on personal interests.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are interested in understanding the biophysics of cancer development and progression. I felt like the first class was more chemical / molecular-focused, whereas the rest of the semester was very much focused on biophysics, which is great so long as that is what a student is interested in! Professor Mak is also a great resource!
yes - if you're interested in learning about physical approaches to cancer, I think it is a very valuable class. I liked that the assignment at the end was writing a review article
Yes! Especially if you're interested in biomechanics and mechanobiology and how it relates to cancer.
Yes, interesting topics and reasonable workload.
